name: Sraosha
subtitle: Yazata of Obedience, Divine Word, and Guardian of Souls
description: Sraosha (Avestan: 'Hearkening' or 'Obedience') stands as one of the most important yazatas (adorable ones) in Zoroastrian theology, embodying the sacred concept of obedient listening to divine revelation and the disciplined observance of religious duties. As the heavenly messenger who bears prayers from earth to heaven, Sraosha functions much like the archangels of Abrahamic traditions. He guards the souls of the righteous during the dangerous three-day journey after death, protecting them from demonic assault as they approach the Chinvat Bridge of judgment. Known as the 'Warrior Yazata,' Sraosha actively battles the forces of evil, particularly the demon Aeshma (fury/wrath), his eternal adversary. His rooster's crow at dawn drives away the demons of the night, making the rooster his sacred animal. Sraosha represents the active, living religion - the divine word heard, understood, and practiced through righteous action.

sections.Origins: Sraosha's origins lie in the Indo-Iranian religious substrate shared with Vedic tradition. His name derives from the Avestan root 'sru-' meaning 'to hear,' cognate with Sanskrit 'shru.' In the earliest Zoroastrian texts, the Gathas of Zarathustra, Sraosha appears as a personification of religious discipline and the obedient hearing of Ahura Mazda's wisdom. He was already among the most venerated yazatas in ancient Iranian religion, his cult surviving the Zoroastrian reformation and becoming central to later developments. The Yasna liturgy dedicates significant sections to Sraosha, and the entire 57th Yasht is devoted to his praise.
sections.Mythology: In Zoroastrian mythology, Sraosha performs several crucial functions. He is the divine messenger who carries prayers and sacrifices from worshippers to Ahura Mazda and the Amesha Spentas in heaven. During the three nights after death, when the soul lingers near the body before judgment, Sraosha stands guard against the demons who seek to claim it. He escorts the righteous soul safely to the Chinvat Bridge, where he participates in the judgment alongside Mithra and Rashnu. His eternal battle against Aeshma, the demon of wrath, represents the struggle between disciplined righteousness and chaotic fury. When the rooster crows at dawn, it is Sraosha's voice calling the faithful to prayer and driving back the creatures of darkness.
sections.Role: Sraosha occupies a unique position in the Zoroastrian divine hierarchy. While not one of the seven Amesha Spentas (the supreme divine beings closest to Ahura Mazda), he stands among the foremost yazatas, sometimes grouped with Mithra and Rashnu as the three divinities presiding over the judgment of souls. His role as guardian of the night makes him the special protector of sleeping humans, and prayers to him form part of the evening devotions. The Srosh Baj, a prayer invoking his protection, is recited during dangerous times and transitions. In temple ritual, he is closely associated with the sacred fire, another force that drives back darkness and evil.
sections.Legacy: Sraosha's influence extends beyond Zoroastrianism into the broader religious history of the Near East and Mediterranean. His role as heavenly messenger carrying prayers between humans and the divine closely parallels Gabriel in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. The Greek god Hermes in his role as psychopomp (soul-guide) shares functions with Sraosha, as does the Egyptian Thoth. The connection between Sraosha and the rooster persists in folk traditions across the Persian-influenced world, where the cock's crow remains associated with the dispersal of evil spirits. In modern Zoroastrian practice, Sraosha remains a beloved and frequently invoked yazata, his name appearing in daily prayers and protective invocations.
